titleStmt.title: Commissions, proclamations, and acts of Privie Councell, concerning Jesuits, Priests, and Papists. 5. July 1642.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Robert Young, and Evan Tyler ...,

notesStmt.note: Imperfect: stained, tightly bound with loss of text.
Contains the texts of two commissions issued by Charles I and one Act of the Privy Council of Scotland.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: COMMISSIONS, PROCLAMATIONS, AND ACTS OF PRIVIE COUNCELL, Concerning Iesuits, Priests, and Papists.
EDINBURGH, Printed by Robert Young, and Evan Tyler, Printers to the Kings most excellent Majestie. Anno 1642.

div.head: COMMISSIONS Against Iesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, and excommunicate Papists.

opener.signed: CHARLES by the grace of GOD, King of great Brittaine, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith,
opener.salute: To Our Lovits, Heralds, Pursevants, Messengers, Our Sheriffs in that part, conjunctly and severally, specially constitute, greeting.

div.p:
Forsameikle as although all Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, excommunicate persons, and traffiquing Papists, are declared by divers Acts of Parliament and secret Councell, to be most pernicious pests in this Common-weale, and avowed enemies to the true Religion, and all Christian government, and were therefore by divers Proclamations, made and published heretofore, of a long time bygone, charged to depart forth of this Our Kingdome, under the pain of death; yet, partly upon occasion of
the comfort and countenance which they find among Our Subjects of all ranks and qualities, popishly affected; and partly by the neglect and over-sight of these, to whose charge, the execution of the saids Acts, and apprehension and punishment of these persons appertained, these Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, have taken the boldnesse from time to time, to repaire to this our Kingdome, bestirring themselves to corrupt simple and ignorant people, both in Religion, and allegeance. And some of thefe Jesuits, and Masse Priests, being craftie and politick heads, and traffiquers in matters of State, bend their whole endeavours by surmises, forging of lies, and dispersing of bruites and rumours of forraigne projects amongst Our Subjects of better sort, to distract them in opinions, and affections, and to entertaine divisions in the State, to the disturbance of the peace of the Countrey: for preventing of whose treasonable attempts, and securing Our Subjects from the snares and dangers, wherein they will not faile to involve them, to their wrack and undoing: Wee, with advice of the Lords of Our Privie Councell, according to the former Orders, issued forth by Our Warrant, and Acts of Our Privie Councell, made with consent of some Commissioners of the State and Kirk for the time, have given and granted, and by the tenour hereof gives and grants full Power and Commission, expresse bidding and charge to the persons particularly under-written, within the bounds following. They are to say, to Sir James Sinclar of Murkill, Sir William Sinclar of Catbell, Sir John Sinclar of Dunbeth, and _____
Bruce of Stanstell, for Our Sherifdome of Caithnes. To Our trusty Cousin and Counseller John Earle of Sutherland, and Our trusty and welbeloved Counseller Sir Robert Gordoun
of _____ and Our Lovits Sir John Gordoun of Embo, George Gordoun, brother to the said Earle, Robert Murray of Spainyedaill, and Robert Gray of Skibo, for Our Sherifdome of Sutherland. And to Our right trusty Cousins and Counsellours, Archibald, Marquesse of Argyle, and George Earle of Seafort, and to Our Lovits, John Mac Cleud of Herreis, and Coline Campbell, Tutor of Caddell, for the bounds of the Iles, And to the said Earle of Seafort, Hugh Master of Lovat, Sir James Fraser, brother to the Lord Lovat, _____ Ros of Ballingowne, Sir John Mac Keinye of Tarbet, and the Provest and Bailiffs of Innernesse for the time, within the Province of Rosse, And to Our trustie Cousin George, Marquesse of Huntlie, and to Our trusty and welbeloved Cousins and Counsellours, James Earle of Murrey, and James Earle of Finlatter, and Our trustie Cousin George, Lord Gordoun, and to Our trustie and welbeloved Counsellours, the said Sir Robert Gordoun, and Sir Robert Innes of that ilk, and to Our Lovits Alexander Dumbar, Sheriffe of Murrey, _____ Brodie of that ilk, _____
Ros of Kilraack, Alexander Abircromby of Birkinboig, Sir Alexander Abircromby his sonne, _____
Ogilvic of Boyne, _____ Ogilvie of Kempicarne, and the Provest and Bailiffs of Elgine, Bamf, Forres, and Narne, for the time being, within the bounds of Our Sherifdomes of Elgine, Forres, Narne, and Bamf, And to the said Marquesse of Hunt lie, William Earle Marshall, Andrew Lord Fraser,
_____ Master of Forbes, Sir Alexander Irwing of Drum, James Crightoun of Fendraucht, Sir Thomas Burnet of Leyes, Sir William Forbes of Cragievar, John Forbes of Leslie, William Seaton of Meany, Walter Forbes of Tolquhoun, Thomas Forbes of Watertoun, Sir William Keith younger of Ludquharne, Alexander Fraser of Phillorth, Thomas Fraser of
Streachin, Alexander Forbes Tutor of Pitsligo, John Keith of Clakriach John Udnye of that ilk, Master Robert Martine in Clarkhill, Walter Ogilme of Ridhyve, _____ Baird of Auchmedden, Thomas Areskine of Pittodrie, John Forbes of Aslown, John Irwing of Beltie, Robert Ferquharson of Innercald, Sir William Forbes of Monymusk, Master James Buchan of Achmacoy, John Forbes in the old town of Aberdene, Master Robert Gordoun of Straloch, and the Provest and Bailiffs of Aberdene for the time, within the bounds of the Province of Aberdene, And to the said Earle Marshall, John Earle of Kingorne, David Earle of Southesk,
_____ Vicount of Arburthnet, James Lord Carnegie, James Master of Duddop, Sir David Grahame of Fintrie, Sir Alexander Areskine of Dun, Sir _____
Grahame of Morphie, Sir Gilbert Ramsay of Balmayne, and the Provest and Bailiffs of Dundie, Forfar, Brechin, and Monrose, within the bounds of Our Sherifdomes of Kincardin, and Forfar, And to Our trustie Cousin and Counsellour, George Earle of Kinnowl, and to Our trustie Cousins, _____ Lord Gask, James Lord Cowper, Andrew Lord Balvard; and to Our Lovits, Sir Robert Campbell of Glenurquhie, Sir Mungo Campbell of Lawers, Sir Patrick Ogilvie of Inchemartine, Sir Thomas Ruthven of Freeland, _____ Blair of Baltheyock, and the Provest and Bailiffs of Perth, within the bounds of the Sherifdomes of Perth, Stratherne, and Monteth, And to Our trustie and welbeloved Cousins and Counsellours, John Earle of Mar, and James Earle of Callander, and to Our trustie Cousin John Lord Areskine, and to Our trustie Cousin and Counsellour, Alexander Lord Elphinstoun, and to Our Lovits, Sir William Murrey of Polmais, _____ Cuningham of Bolquhen, Sir Charles Arskyn of Bandeth, and the Provest and
Bailiffs of Sterline, for Our Sherifdome of Sterline, And to Our right trustie Cousins and Counsellours, William Earle of Morton, Charles Earle of Dumfermline, John Earle of Lindesay, John Earle of Weims, John Lord Sinclar, Robert Lord Burghlie,
_____ Lord Balcarres, and to Our trustie Counsellours, Sir Alexander Gibson of Durie, Clerk Register, and Sir Thomas Hope of Craighall, Our Advocate, and to Our trustie and welbelovits, Sir James Learmonth of Balcolmie, and Sir John Leslie of Newtoun, and Sir _____
Sandelance of Sanctmonance, and William Rig of Athernie, and the Provest and Bailiffs of Our Burrowes in Fyfe, for that Sherifdome, And to Our trustie Cousins and Counsellours, John Earle of Lauderdail, William Earle of Dalhoussie, and Archibald Lord Angus, and to Our trustie Cousin John Lord Maitlane, and to Our trustie Cousin and Counsellour, John Lord Yester, and to Our trustie Cousin, John Lord Cranstoun, and to Our trustie and welbeloved Counsellours, Sir Patrick Hepburne of Wauchton, and Sir George Dundas of that ilk, And to Our trustie and welbelovits, Sir Adam Hepburne of Humbie, one of the Senatours of the Colledge of Justice, Sir John Hamilton of Preston, and Sir John Sinclar of Hirdmestoun, and the Provest and Bailiffs of the Burrowes within the Sherifdomes of Edinburgh, and Hadintoun for that bounds, And to Our right trustie Cousins, James Earle of Annandaill, William Earle of Queensberrie, John Vicount of Kenmure, William Lord Crightoun,
_____ Lord Dalyell, Thomas Lord Kirkcudbright, James Lord Johnstoun, Sir Robert Greir of Lag, _____ Charters of Armsfield, _____ Kirkpatrick of Closburne, James Crighton, son to the Earle of Dumfreis, William Douglas of Kelheid, Master George Douglas
of Penyerie, Colonell William Stuart, James Douglas of Monswald, John Crightoun of Crawf • rston, _____ Jardan of Apilgirth, James Johnston of Corheid, the Provest and Bailifs of Dumfreis, Wigton, and Kircu • bright, Alexander Gordon of Erleston, _____ Gordon of Cardyns, Richard Mure of Cassincarie, John Lenox of Kellie, William Gordon of _____
Gordon of Craichlaw, George Glendoning of Lothin, James Mac Dougall of Garthland, the Sheriffe of Galloway, _____ Mac Dougall of Frenche,
_____ of Logan, and _____
Johnston of Westraw, within the bounds of Wigtoun, Dumfreis, Kirkcudbright, and Annandaill, And to Our trustie Cousins and Counsellours, John Earle of Lowdoun, Lord Chancellour, Alexander Earle of Eglinton, John Earle of Cassiles, and to Our Lovits, Sir William Cuningham of Caprinton, Sir _____
Crawfurd of Kelburne, Sir Lodowick Houston of that ilk, Sir William Mure of Rowallan,
_____
Birsbane of Bishopton, _____ Porterfield of Deuchan, and Sir William Cochran of Cowdon, within the bounds of Air, Irwing, and Renfrew, to passe, search, seek, and take all and sundrie Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, and excommunicate, traffiquing, rebellious Papists, where ever they may be apprehended, and whose names shall be given to them by the Moderatour of the Presbyterie, or any one of the Ministers of the Presbyterie, or whose names shall be sent to them by Our Councell, or of whom they have certain knowledge themselves, and to put, hold, and detaine them in sure firmance and captivitie, ay and while order and direction be given for their punishment, as accords. With power to Our saids Commissioners, conjunctly and severally, by their best endeavours, to restraine the superstitious going in pilgrimages to Chappells, and Wells, which hath been very frequent
in this Our Kingdome, to the offence of God, scandall of the Kirk, and disgrace of Our governement. And for this effect, to cause diligent attendance be given at such parts and places where this idolatrous superstition is used, and to apprehend all persons of whatsoever qualitie, whom they shall deprehend, going in pilgrimages to Chappells and Wells, or whom they shall know themselves to be guiltie of that crime, and to commit and detaine them in ward, till order shall bee given for their punishment, conforme to the Lawes of the Countrey. And if it shall happen the saids Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, and excommunicate, traffiquing, and rebellious Papists, or any of them, for eschewing of apprehension, to flee to strengths and houses, With power to Our saids Commissioners, conjunctly and severally, to doe therein according as is prescribed by our Lawes in case of rebellion: And generally with power to Our saids Commissioners conjunctly and severally to doe, exerce and use all and sundrie other things, which for apprehension of the saids Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, and excommunicate, rebellious Papists, and persons superstitiously going to Pilgrimages and Wels, by Law and Consuetude of this Our Realme, may lawfully be done firme and stable, holding, and for to hold, all and whatsoever things shall be lawfully done herein.

OUR WILL IS HEREFORE, and Wee charge you straitly and command, that incontinent these Our Letters seen, you passe to the market Crosses of the Head Burrowes of Our Sherifdomes particularly above-written, and by open Proclamation make publication hereof, and that you command and charge all Our Lieges and Subjects, to reverence, acknowledge and obey, rise, concurre, fortifie and assist Our
said Commissioners, conjunctly and severally, in all and every thing tending to the execution of this Our Commission: And for this effect to conveene and meet with them at such dayes, times and places as they shall bee advertised by their missive Letters, or otherwayes; and effaldly and truely to concurre and joyne with them in this Commission, and to doe nothing which may hinder and impede the same, or linger and delay the execution thereof, as they and every one of them will testifie their affection to the true Religion, and punishing the adversaries thereof, and under the paine to bee pursued and punished, as favourers, suppliers, countenancers, and assisters of the saids Jesuites, Seminary and Masse Priests, and excommunicate rebellious Papists: And that you command and charge Our saids Commissioners to accept this Commission upon them, and faithfully and carefully to execute the same, and to bee ready at all times, as they shall be required or advertised of the being of the saids Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, or excommunicate rebellious Papists, in any part within the bounds allotted to them; to rise and go forward for their pursuit and apprehension, as they will approve themselves worthy of the trust reposed in them, and will answer on the contrary at their perill. The which to doe, We commit to you conjunctly and severally Our full power, by these Our Letters, delivering the same by you duelie execute and indorsed again to the bearer.

closer.dateline: Given under Our Signet at Edinburgh the 5. day of July, and of Our Reigne the 18. year, 1642.

div.head: CHARGES Against Iesuits, and Masse Priests, to depart out of the Countrey.

opener.signed: CHARLES by the grace of GOD, King of great Brittaine, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith,
opener.salute: To Our Lovits Heralds Pursevants Messengers, Our Sheriffes, in that part conjunctly and severally, specially constitute, greeting.

div.p:
Forsameikle as the Lords of Our Privie Councell are informed, that divers Children of Noblemen, and others Our subjects of this Our Kingdome, have bin heretofore sent over into Seminarie Colledges, and other Popish houses beyond Sea, and there instructed, perswaded, and strengthened in their Popish errors, where-through they become not onely corrupt and perverted in their Religion, but poysoned and infected in their duty and allegeance to Us, and alienated in their naturall love and affection to their Countrey, which is so much the more dangerous, because the poyson being infused into youths and students, as into new vessells, groweth in time to an inveterate habit of malice, against the present government. As also that divers Jesuits and Seminarie Priests, haunt, frequent, and are reset in the houses of many of the Subjects of this Our Kingdome, whereby there is a dayly growth and increase of Papists: And We fearing the dangerous consequences
that hereupon may follow, and being carefull to prevent the same, and therewithall being desirous to notifie Our readinesse and constant resolution to maintaine the true Religion professed, and by Law established, as upon all occasions to represse the contrarie: Therefore according to a former Act and Proclamation, emitted by Our Warrant of the date the first of November, 1625.

OUR WILL IS, and Wee charge you straitly and command, that incontinent these Our Letters seen, you passe to the market crosses of the head Burrowes of this Our Kingdome, and other places needfull, and make publication thereof: And that you command and charge all the saids Children that betwixt and the first day of January next, they return to this their native Countrey, and conform themselves to live in such duty and obedience as becomes good Subjects, and that their Parents, Tutors, and Governours, and such others, as have been, or are faultie either in sending, permitting, or maintaining them there, take present order to recall them home, and provide that they be returned to this Our Kingdome, betwixt and the day foresaid, and that none be sent over, permitted to goe, or maintained there hereafter, under the paine of the uttermost severitie of Justice to be extended in that behalf and inflicted upon them. And such like that you command, charge, and inhibite, that no Priest, nor other Person, having taken, or who shall take order by, or under any authority, or power, derived from the Sea of Rome, whether they be naturall borne Subjects, or Strangers, do presume to confer any Ecclesiasticall order, or exercise any Ecclesiasticall jurisdiction, or function whatsoever, towards, or upon
any Our naturall borne Subjects of this Our Kingdome. As likewise, that you command and charge all and sundry Judges, and Justices, to whom it appertaineth, to put all Our Laws and Statutes now standing in force against Jesuits, Seminarie Priests, and others, having taken orders from the Sea of Rome, being Our Subjects, to due and full execution, against such of them as from, and after the last day of September next to come, shall be found within this Our Kingdome. Which day We have limitted and prefixed for the uttermost terme of their departure. As also that you command, charge, and inhibite all Our Lieges and Subjects, that none of them presume nor take upon hand, after the said day, to reset, supply, harbour, entertaine, releeve, or conceale any of the saids Jesuits, Seminarie Priests, or other Popish Priests, under the paines provided by Our Lawes in that behalf, Which paines shall be severely inflicted upon the offenders, without favour. And last, that you command and charge all Our Subjects, of whatsoever ranke and degree, to conforme themselves to the publike profession of the true Religion now established, like as We prohibite the exercise of any contrarie profession, under the paines contained in Our Lawes and Statutes made hereanent. And We ordain all Synods and Presbyteries to proceed against all such as are knowne to be of a contrarie profession, according to the Lawes of the Kirk and Realme. The which to doe, We commit to you, conjunctly and severally, Our full power, by these Our Letters, delivering the same by you, duely execute, and indorsed again to the bearer.

closer.dateline: Given under Our Signet at Edinburgh the 5 of July, and of Our Reigne the 18 year. 1642.

div.head: ACTS OF COUNCELL, Concerning Iesuits, Priests, and excommunicate Papists. At Edinburgh the fifth day of July 1642.
div.p:
FOrsameikle as although the reset, suplie, and intercommuning with Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests (who by divers Acts of Parliament were found to be profest and avowed enemies to all Christian government) have been straitly discharged by many good Acts of Parliament, Convention, and secret Councell, under certain paines contained therein: Notwithstanding it is of truth that the reset, supply, and comforting of these unhappy People, is very frequent, in divers parts of this Kingdome: partly upon occasion of by-past connivence, and over-sight, given to persons offending in this kinde, and partly because particular Commissions have not been granted for tryall of the saids resets, which is the chief and speciall cause whereby these Jesuits and Masse Priests are encouraged to repair to this Kingdome, and to take libertie to corrupt His Majesties Subjects both in their Religion and Allegeance: whereas if these resets, and starting-holes were denyed unto them, the Countrey would not be troubled with their treasonable projects and insinuations: Therefore the Lords of secret Councell, according to an Act of Parliament, made in the moneth
of June, 1609. and to former Acts of secret Councell, and to the 13. Act of the Parliament, holden at Edinburgh in September, 1640. ordains and commands all and sundry Synods and Presbyteries within this Kingdome, and with that gives and grants unto them full Power and Commission, to call and conveene before them, all and sundry persons resetters of Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests, & excommunicat Rebells for Poperie, and all hearers and sayers of Masse, at such dayes and times as they shall appoint; and for this effect, to fence and hold Courts, and to create officers and members of Court needfull, and the person or persons guilty of the crimes above-written, or any of them, to call and accuse, and to deduce and lead probation thereupon, either by oath of party, or by witnesses. And in case any person resetter being lawfully summoned to compeir and answer upon the said reset, will notwithstanding wilfully absent himself, and shun his tryall, and so take the crime upon him, that in that case they hold him as confest: Providing alwayes, that the partie reset be specially condescended upon, either by his own proper name, or by the name and designation which he assumes to himself, and whereby he is known in the Countrey, and that the reset hath been within the space of one year: And the said tryall and probation being taken, that they report the same to the Lords of Privie Councell, or to His Majesties Advocate, to the intent the Delinquents may be called to their answer, and punished accordingly. With power to the saids Synods and Presbyteries, every one within their own bounds, and offices, to call before them all persons who against the tenour of the Acts of Parliament, 1609. and 1640. refuse to communicate; and to take tryall of their refusall, And if thereupon they
shall be found non-communicants, that they report the same to the Councell, that they may fine them: Which fines are to be applyed to the uses prescribed, by the said Act of the late Parliament. And recommends to the said Synods and Presbyteries, to have a speciall care to put this Commission to execution in all points.

The Lords of secret Councell, according to a former Act of Councell, made in July 1629. declares, and ordaines, that no excommunicate Rebells who shall be warded for matters of Religion, shall be releeved out of ward, but upon obedience and conformitie to the true Religion, or else upon their voluntarie offer of banishment forth of His Majesties whole Dominions.

Forsameikle as by divers Acts of Parliament, Convention, and secret Councell, made and published heretofore, it is ordained, that no person nor persons whatsoever who professeth not the true Religion presently profest within this Kingdome, shall be preferred to any office whatsoever without exception, or restriction. Therefore the saids Lords, conforme to the saids Acts, declares and ordaines, that no profest Papist, refusing to communicate being required thereto, shall have place in Councell, Session, or any other Judicatory, nor bruike any office within this Kingdome, and ordaines these whom it concerns, to have a speciall care of the precise observation of the saids Acts. And such like the saids Lords prohibits and discharges all persons whatsoever, being under processe for Poperie, to resort or repaire to His Majesties Court without Licence from the saids Lords, under the paine to be called, pursued, and punished as contemners of the directions of His Majesties Councell.

Forsameikle as there have been divers Acts of Parliament
and secret Councell made anent the education of Noblemens Children, which have been neglected, and not received execution these divers yeers by-gone; where-through divers youths, as well the sons of noblemen, as others, have been, and are very much corrupted in their Religion: Therefore the Lords of secret Councell ordaines the saids Acts of Parliament to be put to execution in all points, conforme to the tenour thereof: And they recommend to the severall Presbyteries of the Kingdome, to make a true report to His Majesties Councell of the names of such Noblemen and Barons sons and daughters, whose parents are suspect in Religion, or where they are bred in suspect places.

The Lords of secret Councell ordaines the names of all excommunicate Papists, given in at this time in a Catalogue and roll, to be affixed upon the Session house of Edinburgh, To the intent the Lords of Session, and others Judges, and the Commissers upon objection of parties, and inspection of the Catalogue, may refuse processe to the partie therein contained.

The Lords ordaines the Synods and Presbyteries of this Kingdome, to proceed against all ranks and conditions of persons suspect of Poperie, with the censures of the Kirk without exception, under the paines contained in the Acts of Parliament.

The Lords ordaines Letters to be direct against excommunicate Papists, being Rebells, to compeir before the Councell, to hear Letters of treason direct against them for rendring their houses, and entring their persons in ward in Blacknes: and that the Summonds against such of them as dwell on this side of Dee, shall be upon ten dayes warning: and against these by
north Dee, upon fifteen dayes: As also that Letters of intercommuning bee direct against them upon lawfull Hornings to be given in for Warrant thereof.

The Lords of secret Councell ordaines that no Letters be granted against Ministers at the instance of excommunicate and Rebellious Papists, but upon caution for payment of the Ministers expences in case they succumbe in proving their complaint: and that Letters be direct against all such persons who shall abuse Ecclesiasticall Judicatories, or threaten to take Ministers lives for their appearance before the Councell to their answer.

The Lords of secret Councell recommends to the Lyon King of armes, to discharge all Messengers of armes suspect of Poperie, and refusing to subscribe the Covenant, being required thereto by the Presbyterie, to execute their office till they conforme.

The Lords of secret Councell recommends to the Lords of Exchequer, to have a speciall care that the escheits and life-rents of excommunicate Papists be only applyed to His Majesties use, and no wayes to the use of the Rebells, directly nor indirectly, and that the intrometters with the same for times by-gone, be called and pursued with convenient diligence. And for this effect to see the 13. Act of the late Parliament, made hereanent observed in every point.

Forsameikle as albeit the reset of Jesuits, Seminarie and Masse Priests have been oft prohibite and discharged, yet the execution of the Lawes made hereanent, hath been illuded by the Wives of persons repute and esteemed to be sound in Religion, who pretending misknowledge of the actions of their Wives in these cases,
think to liberate themselves of the danger of the reset, as if they were not to answer for their Wives doings; and under colour hereof, Jesuits an • Masse Priests are hoorded in divers parts of the Kingdome, and occasion •… hereby offered to corrupt the Ch • ldren, and servants of •… he House in their Religion. For • emeid whereof con
•… orme to a former Act of Councell it is hereby decla
•… ed, that the Husband shall be answerable and compt
•… ble to His Majesties Councell and Justice of the Kingdome, that his Wife being a profest • apist, or under •… rocesse for Poperie, shall not reset, sup • lie, nor inter
•… ommune with Jesuits, nor Priests, A • d that he nor •… he, shall not be served by Papists, and th • t none shall •… e admitted to their service, but such as h • ve a Testi
